Blood group antigens are ABO antigens, Rhesus antigens and minor antigens

Rhesus antigens are C,c,D,E,e. There is no ‘d’ antigen

Incidence of Rh-ve blood group - 5-10%

All Rhesus antigens are located on short arm of chr.1

Incidence of Rh D alloimmunisation with out ABO incompatibility is 16%

Incidence of Rh D alloimmunisation with ABO incompatibility is 2%

Most common non D Rhesus alloimmunisation is anti E

Most severe non D Rhesus alloimmunisation is anti-c

Minor antigens

-Kell

-Duffy group A (anti Fya)

-anti MNS

-anti JK Kidd

Fetal hemolysis are not caused by

lewis antibodies Lea,Leb

I antibodies

Duffy group B anti Fyb

Cause of Rh alloimmunisation - pregnancy > blood transfusion

Cause of minor antigen alloimmunisation - blood transfusion > Pregnancy

Kell sensitization due to pregnancy is more severe than Rh-D sensitsation

Features of Kell sensitization due to pregnancy

-Affects bone narrow erythrocyte precursors

- Less hematopoesis

- Less hemolysis and less Jaundice

- Less antibody titre

- Ideal investigation is MCA Doppler

questions.text: Cardinal movements of labour are

24 year old G2P1L1 with 32 weeks of gestation has come with pain abdomen with a blood pressure of 150/90 mm Hg. Patient gives history of raised BP in her previous pregnancy which continued to be elevated for 8 weeks postpartum. Patient also gives history of excessive wt gain in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters in the present pregnancy. O/E patient has severe B/L pedal edema extending upto knees with edema of hands and face. Most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Definition

  • Pregnant women with Blood pressure ≥ 140/90 mmHg is considered Hypertensive


Any hypertension during pregnancy diagnosed beore 20 weeks of gestation or which continues to persist for more than 12 weeks postpartum is chronic hypertension. Edema is no longer a criteria for the diagnosis of preeclampsia

Pre-Eclampsia

  • Hypertension (B.P > 140/90 mm hg)

With Proteinuria ≥ 300mg / 24 hours

1 + Dipstick /

Urine Protein creatinine Ratio ≥ 0.3

(OR)

Any of the following complication

Thrombocytopenia - (Platelet < 1lakh)

Renal Insufficiency (S. Creatinine > 1.1mg% or Doubling of Baseline S. Creatinine value)

Liver involvement ( S. Transaminase levels twice - normal )

Cerebral symptoms - Headache, visual disturbances, Pulmonary edema

questions.text: Alpha subunit of HCG is similar to all except
questions.solution:
Other Important Notes and recent Questions based on the chapter AND HIGHLY PROBABLE QUESTIONS

HCG is a glycoprotein encoded by single gene on chr. 6.

Secreted predominantly by syncitiotrophoblast but cytotrophoblast also contributes before 5 weeks

Molecular weight 36,000-40,000 dalton

Non specific alpha subunit (92 AA)

Specific Beta subunit (145 AA)

Alpha subunit is similar to TSH, FSH & LH

T1/2-36hours

Doubling time-1.4 to 2 days

Can be detected earliest by 8-9 days post conception

Maximum level is seen at 60-80 days ( 8 to 10 weeks) of pregnancy (100-200 IU/mL), then starts declining till 16 weeks and then plateaus

Concentration in maternal serum> amniotic fluid > fetal serum

HCG disappears from circulation within 2 weeks following delivery

questions.text: Volume of blood in the intervillous space is
questions.solution:
Other Important Notes and recent Questions based on the chapter AND HIGHLY PROBABLE QUESTIONS

Summary of intervillous Hemodynamics:

  • Volume of blood in mature placenta - 500 mL
  • Volume of blood in intervillous space - 150 mL
  • Blood flow in intervillous space - 500-600 mL/min
  • Pressure in itervillous space:
  • During uterine contraction - 30-50 mm Hg
  • During uterine relaxation - 10-15 mm Hg
  • Pressure in the supplying uterine artery - 70-80 mm Hg
  • Pressure in the draining uterine vein - 8 mm Hg

HBA1C is the best method to rule out overt diabetes in the first trimester

Gestational Diabetes

00:05:06

  • Any degree of glucose intolerance diagnosed for first time during pregnancy irrespective of gestational age & parity

Overt Diabetes- Definition

  • Fasting ≥ 126mg%
  • Random sugar ≥ 200mg%
  • Hb A1C > 6.

questions.text: Amniocentesis in an immunized Rh positive woman shows zone 3 of lilleys curve. Ideal management for her would be
questions.solution:
Other Important Notes and recent Questions based on the chapter AND HIGHLY PROBABLE QUESTIONS

Protocols for managing a Rh immunized antenatal woman

Do ICT at booking visit and at 28 weeks and if ICT is negative at 28 weeks give anti-D 300 micrograms

If ICT is positive in low titres, 1:4 and below repeat titre 2 weekly

If titre is positive in 1:8 and above do doppler of middle cerebral artery peak systopic velocity 2 weekly

If MCA PSV doppler is less than 1.5 MOM repeat doppler 2 weekly

If MCA PSV doppler is more than 1.5 MOM do amniocentesis and plot in Liley's graph

Zone 1 - repeat amnio 4 weekly

Zone 2 - repeat amnio 2 weekly

Zone 3 - Intra uterine transfusion

questions.text: Levonorgestrel is a
questions.solution:
Other Important Notes and recent Questions based on the chapter AND HIGHLY PROBABLE QUESTIONS

Classifications of Progesterone:

  • Pure progesterone- Oral and vaginal micronized progesterone have no adverse effect on lipid profile
  • Pregnane (derived from progesterone molecule), lynes-trenol (allyloestrenol)
  • Estrane (derivative of testosterone)- Norethisterone, norethinyndiol (1st generation)
  • Gonane-Levonorgestrel, norgestrel (2nd generation)
  • 3rd generation progesterone (desogestrel, gestodene, norgestimate). These are less androgenic and cause less metabolic disorders but increase the risk of thrombosis

Drospirenone (3 mg equivalent to 25 mg spirinone) now used in oral pills, acne and PCOD. Yasmin contains 30 μg of EE 2 (21 days), Janya contains 20 μg of EE 2 for 24 days in a cycle

questions.text: 26 year old G2P1 with past history of tuberculosis has come for the booking visit. High chances of relapse occurs in
questions.solution:
Other Important Notes and recent Questions based on the chapter AND HIGHLY PROBABLE QUESTIONS

Tuberculosis in Pregnancy

  • Increased chances of relapse and flare of tuberculosis occurs in puerperium
  • It is not an indication for termination of pregnancy
  • ATT can be given at anytime during pregnancy, including first trimester
  • INH + Rifampicin are given orally for 9 months
  • Baby should be given prophylactic INH for 3 months, if montoux is negative after 3 months, stop INH and give injection BCG
  • In active lesions breast feeding is C/I, ATT is not a C/I for breast feeding
  • Pulmonary TB is not an indication for performing cesarean section

ATT C/I During Pregnancy:

  • Kanamycin
  • Floroquinolones
  • Capreomycin

questions.text: The first parameter to disappear in a biophysical profile during fetal hypoxia is
questions.solution:
Other Important Notes and recent Questions based on the chapter AND HIGHLY PROBABLE QUESTIONS



Fetal tone begins by 7-8 weeks, fetal movements by 9 weeks, breathing movements by 20 - 21 weeks and heart rate reactivity by 26- 28 weeks. In the presence of progressive hypoxia reactivity in NST and fetal breathing movements are the first biophysical profile to disappear followed by cessation of fetal movements and finally fetal tone

questions.text: Not a property of third generation progesterone
questions.solution:
Other Important Notes and recent Questions based on the chapter AND HIGHLY PROBABLE QUESTIONS

Cerozette containing 75μg desogestrel has the following advantages over other POPs

  • Stringent time compliance not necessary, as it supresses ovulation in 97%, throuhg pituitary hormone suppression.
  • No androgenic effects like acne.
  • No ectopic pregnancy, no eect on carbohydrate or lipid metabolism
  • Failure rate only 0.21 per 100 women yrars. It acts through metabolic etonogestrel which binds to progesterone receptors

Complications of desogestrel are:

  • Deep venous thrombosis
  • Pulmonary embolism, breast cancer, liver disease, aprt from common complications of progestogens.

questions.text: 26year old G2P1L1 with 12 weeks pregnancy presents with 3rd degree UV prolapse. True about the following condition are all except
questions.solution:
Other Important Notes and recent Questions based on the chapter AND HIGHLY PROBABLE QUESTIONS

  1. The incidence of prolapse during pregnancy is very rare. It usually occurs in multiparous women. Most cases are pregnancies in pre existing prolapse.

As far as the options are concerned always remember that the maximum size of the uterus that can descend through the vagina is 12 weeks. Beyond 12 weeks uterus becomes an abdominal organ and is well supported by pelvic brim. Hence in the second trimester it spontaneously resolves.

For prolapses which does not resolve spontaneously ring Pessary should be adequate.

In cases where prolapse develops during pregnancy it appears during late second or third trimester.

If the condition is unattended and the cervix is lying constantly outside the introitus, it can become edematous, ulcerated and irreducible. Other complications during pregnancy include UTI, preterm labor, PPROM, sepsis and urinary retention. Cervical dystocia may occur during labor and there is risk of rupture of lower segment although cervical dilation and spontaneous vaginal delivery occurs in most cases since they occur in multiparous women. Hence it is not an absolute indication for cesarean section.

choices.text: Point A is 2cm above and lateral to external OS
Point B is 4cm lateral to point A
Point B corresponds to obturator nodes

questions.text: All are true about radiotherapy for Ca Cx except
questions.solution:
Other Important Notes and recent Questions based on the chapter AND HIGHLY PROBABLE QUESTIONS

  • Radiotherapy is the treatment of choice for Ca Cx Stage 1b2 and above.
  • Primary radiation treatment plan consists of a combination of external teletherapy to treat the regional lymph nodes and to decrease the tumour volume and brachytherapy delivered by intracavitary applicators or interstitial implants to treat the central tumour.
  • The usual doses delivered are 7000 to 8000 cGy to point A defined as 2 cm superior to external os and 2 cm lateral to internal uterine canal and 6000 cGy to point B Defined as 3 cm lateral to point A.
  • Point A corresponds to the point of crossing of uterine Artery with the ureter.
  • Point B corresponds to obturator nodes.

questions.text: 27 year old primigravida with 32 weeks of gestation presents with pruritis with Icterus. Investigations revealed S.Bilirubin -5mg%, S.ALP-200mg%, ALT is 30IU/L. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Other Important Notes and recent Questions based on the chapter AND HIGHLY PROBABLE QUESTIONS

  • Obstetric cholestasis or intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy typically occurs in late pregnancy.
  • Pruritis in the palms and soles, severe at night is characteristic of this condition.
  • Most patients don't develop clinical jaundice.
  • The characteristic lab abnormality is high serum bile acid of > 10 mmol/L and may be elevated upto 100 fold.
  • Other findings are conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, modest increase in serum ALP.
  • GGT and serum amino transferase are normal or minimally elevated.
  • OC progresses until delivery and resolves within 24 to 48 hours of delivery.
  • Condition recurs in subsequent pregnancies.
  • Foetal abnormalities include increased risk of intrapartum fetal distress, meconium aspiration, preterm delivery and stillbirth.
  • Management includes UDCA, calamine lotion, oral vitamin K and elective delivery at 37-38 weeks.

Most commons in Fibroid:

  • Fibroids are most commonly Uterine
  • MC uterine fibroid is interstitial
  • All fibroids to begin with start as an interstitial fibroid
  • MC extra uterine fibroid is cervical fibroid
  • A pedunculated subserous fibroid sometimes detached itself from the uterus and gets attached to a vascular organ and exists independently - Parasitic fibroid
  • Most symptomatic fibroid is submucous fibroid
  • MC fibroid causing retention of urine - Anterior and Central cervical fibroids
  • MC fibroid to undergo necrosis - submucous fibroid
  • MC fibroid to undergo calcareous degeneration - subserous
  • MC fibroid to undergo malignant change - submucous
  • Lantern on St.Paul's church refers to a cervical fibroid

MC fibroid to undergo torsion - Pedunculated subserous fibroid

choices.text: Quintero staging is used to assess its severity

questions.text: True regarding TRAP sequence
questions.solution:
Other Important Notes and recent Questions based on the chapter AND HIGHLY PROBABLE QUESTIONS

  • TRAP sequence/Acardiac twin complicates 1% of mono chorionic twins.
  • In TRAP sequence the normal twin acts as a pump twin which donates blood to the abnormal twin called recipient twin through an abnormal artery to artery or venous to venous communication in the placenta. This results in reversal of flow in the umbilical cord vessel of the recipient twin. Oxygenated blood enters the foetus through umbilical artery and deoxygenated blood leaves through umbilical vein.

As a result of this imbalance in the circulation lower body develops well compared to upper segment. There is atrophy of the heart while organs such as head, limbs and upper intestines do not develop.

Associated congenital anomalies are present in 9% of pump twin. These include single umbilical artery in 66% and chromosomal abnormality in the Acardiac twin in 33%.

questions.text: The most accepted criteria for defining hyperemesis gravidarum include all except
questions.solution:
Other Important Notes and recent Questions based on the chapter AND HIGHLY PROBABLE QUESTIONS

Hyperemesis occurs in 0.3-1.5% women and usually needs hospitalization.

The most accepted criteria for defining hyperemesis gravidarum are

  1. persistent vomiting resulting in dehydration,
  2. weight loss greater than 3kg or 5%, starvation
  3. associated electrolyte imbalance and ketonuria.

The condition in commoner in first than in subsequent pregnancies.

Epigastric tenderness is frequently noted. In the later stages, the temperature starts to raise, jaundice supervenes and haematemesis may occur. She becomes apathetic and drowsy or confused and euphoric. Squint, diplopia and nystagmus may be noted and retinal haemorrhages appear.

Various palsies develop and there may be great tenderness in the legs together with other signs of peripheral neuritis.

Ultimately, Wernicke's encephalopathy becomes fully established and the patient usually dies in coma.

questions.solution:
Other Important Notes and recent Questions based on the chapter AND HIGHLY PROBABLE QUESTIONS

AFP is produced from fetal yolk sac, liver and GIT. It is the most abundant protein in serum of fetus.

AFP passes from urine of fetus into amniotic fluid and enters maternal serum by diffusion.

Therefore any defect in fetus wall will result in more of mixing in amniotic fluid and hence increased MSAFP

MSAFP

questions.text: False statement about the staging of vulval cancer is
questions.solution:
Other Important Notes and recent Questions based on the chapter AND HIGHLY PROBABLE QUESTIONS

High yielding Facts about vulvar cancer


Vulvar lesions require biopsy to avoid delay in diagnosis

  • The modern approach to patients with vulvar cancer is multidisciplinary and individualized
  • Management of the primary lesion and groin nodes is determined separately
  • Most t1,t2 and early t3 lesionsssss can be managed with radical local excision
  • Large t3 and t4 primary tumors are best treated with chemoradiation followed by more limited surgical resection
  • When groin dissection is indicated it should be a thorough inguinofemoral lymphe
  • The potential role of sentinel lymph node procedure to eliminate the need of a complete inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy is being investigated
  • The single most important prognostic factor is lymph node status
  • Postoperative radiation decreases the risk of groin recurrence in patients with multiple positive inguino femoral lymph nodes
  • Recurrence in the groin is almost universally fatal

Stages of Iron deficiency anemia

  • Stage 1- Depletion of iron stores
  1. ferritin falls
  • Stage 2- Iron deficient hematopoeisis
  1. ↓ S.ferritin< 20ng/ml
  2. ↓ transferrin saturation<20% (S. Iron/TIBC)
  3. ↓ S. Iron< 60 mic gram/dl
  4. ↑ in protoporphyrin
  5. ↑ in TIBC
  6. ↑ in transferrin receptor

Stage 3.- Frank iron deficiency anemia

↓ Hb, MCV, MCH, MCHC, hematocrit

TIBC and transferring levels increase with pregnancy
